prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use ALMA Band 7 to detect the dust continuum from the GRB host galaxies. Band 7 is chosen because of its great sensitivity to dust with opacity law of beta of ~1.0-1.5. We will adopt the nominal frequency of Band 7.
Our aim is detection, so we do not request a high angular resolution. Our requested 1 arcsec resolution should give a good surface brightness sensitivity without missing much flux, given the typical size of high-z optically selected galaxies (<1 arcsec).
For the range of extinction corrected star formation rates (SFRs) of our targets (10 to >100 Msun/yr, Table 1), their expected Band 7 fluxes are around 0.3 mJy. We request a uniform sensitivity for all our targets to avoid bias from the optical determinations of the SFRs. To securely detect our targets, we request a significance level of 7 sigma, i.e., an rms noise of 0.043 mJy.
We do not request special calibration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Studies of distant starburst galaxies hosting GRBs offer unique insights into extreme star-forming regions during early epochs. In particular, 25-40% of all GRBs show a suppressed optical to x-ray ratio in the afterglow. A likely explanation is that they originate in dusty galaxies, which are commonly missed in optical surveys. We have carried out a successful program in ALMA Cycle 0 to observe the galaxy hosting the dark GRB 080607 at z = 3.036. We obtained a marginal detection of its 345 GHZ continuum, placing it at the faintest end of the dusty galaxy population. The result indicates that the large extinction (Av ~ 3) in the afterglow is confined along a dusty sight line, contrary to the expectation of the host galaxy itself being dusty. Here we propose deep imaging of the 345 GHz continuum from a larger sample of six galaxies hosting dust-obscured GRBs at z > 1.5. All six galaxies have spectroscopic redshifts to confirm that the suppressed optical fluxes are indeed due to extinction, rather than IGM absorption. The proposed imaging will allow us to characterize the global dust content of the host galaxies and put them in a broader context of the dusty galaxy population.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy & Astrophysics, Chicago, University of
